description: Ivory Coast will start its vaccination campaign from 15 February 2021. This aiming 100 000 vulnerable or exposed people with 200 000 doses.
type_sub_cat: Administering of the vaccine (i.e. giving people the vaccine shot)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The first phase of Ivorian vaccination campaign will start in the 1st of march to 10th of March 2021. This first phase will only concern the state of Abidjan and aims to vaccinate 2 groups. The first group is made up of health personnel, defense and security forces as well as teachers. The second group is made up of people over 50, carriers of chronic pathologies and travelers.
type_sub_cat: Administering of the vaccine (i.e. giving people the vaccine shot)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Ivorian government is announcing that the vaccination program will start from April 2021. This will concern around 5 M people, around 20% of the national population. The targeted population is: health workers, defence and security forces, teachers, people over the age of 50, people with chronic conditions and international travellers.
type_sub_cat: Regulatory approval process for administering the COVID-19 vaccine
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The Ivory Coast declares the State of Emergency.

description: The Ivorian Government has declared a state of Health Emergency in all territory/provinces in Ivory Coast starting from 21st of January to 28th of February 2021. This declaration means an intensification of the obligation to wear a mask, in particular in public transport, public and private services and all public spaces.

description: The Ivory Coast is enforcing a travel ban for all non- citizens entering from a country that has more than a hundred confirmed COVID- 19 cases. All non- Ivorian permanent residents and Ivorian coming back will be quarantined for a period of two weeks in government locals. This measure took effect on the 16th of March and will be valid for a period of 15 days, with a possibility to renew the policy.

description:
The Ivory Coast's Minister of Health and Hygiene announced on the 27th of March the national directives concerning the treatment of patients with the Coronavirus: 
In the case that the patient does not present grave symptoms, they are to stay quarantined at home.
Severe cases will be taken in charge by health services.
Cases that have had complications will be taken into intensive care.

description:
Ivorian Coast monitoring committee of the Muslim community is enforcing 5 new measures to secure the opening of mosques from May 7 :
1. The 5 obligatory prayers are allowed in the mosques inside the country
2. Opening of an entrance and exit for men and an entrance and exit for women
3. Each entrance will need a hand washing
4. The mosque will close after each obligatory prayer
5. The organization of Tafsirs, sermons, group breaks and prayers of Tarawih and Tahadjoud must respect the security measures established by the government
type_text: Religious practice
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Ivory Coast is providing the Health department with 110 tablets, 11 desktops, 11 laptops, 15 lab printers with cryogenic labels, 7 desktop printers, 15 barcode readers and 13 wifi connection points. description: WHO is reinforcing the remote training scheme of INSP and 85 health districts in Ivory Coast. Donations include laptops and desktops, cabinets, inverters, stabilizers, fly box internet, cameras with tripods and microphones, mixing tables, TV sets, sound bars, internet servers and all accessories, this initial investment is estimated at FCFA 300 million. This has been announced on June 5th.

description:
Ivory Coast will be receiving a 2.2 billion CFA francs from Japan to enable it to carry out an effective fight against Covid-19.
Japanese aid will be used to strengthen the medical capacity of five hospitals in Greater Abidjan. These are the university hospitals of Cocody, Yopougon, Angré and Treichville, as well as the general hospital of Anyama. This after July 6th.

description: The Ivory Coast is enforcing a ban "on gatherings of more than 50 people during a period of 15 days, with a possibility to be renewed, starting on the 18th of March at midnight".

Ivory Coast is maintaining the restriction measures in Abidjan district exclusively concerning the closure of restaurants, maquis, bars, nightclub and venue of performances. Population gatherings of more than 50 people remain in force. These will be lifted on Friday, May 15

The Ivory Coast is relaxing the measures restricting the assembly of populations, initially capped at 50 people, they now increase to 200 people after May 8 UPDATE: Measures restricting the assembly of populations initially capped at 50 people now increases to 200 people

Ivory Coast is maintaining the restriction measures in Abidjan district exclusively concerning the closure of restaurants, maquis, bars, nightclub and venue of performances. Population gatherings of more than 50 people remain in force. These will be lifted June 30. UPDATE: The number of people allowed in a rally goes from 200 to 50 in greater Abidjan till June 30.

Ivory Coast is stopping the ban on mass gathering and restrictions for bars, night clubs, cinemas and venues from July 31st. UPDATE: The original ban of mass gatherings will be stopped on July 31st for bars, night clubs, cinemas and venues.
The Ivory Coast demands that all citizens "maintain a distance of a meter between [each other] in all supermarkets, bars, restaurants, companies, airports and public spaces" after March 16.
The Ivory Coast prohibits"hand-shaking, embraces and hugs"
The Ivory Coast's ministry of transports forbids the accompanying and welcoming of travelers in airports.
